           <td class="blob-line-code"><div class="code-body highlight"><pre><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC1'>---</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC2'>output:</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC3'>&nbsp;&nbsp;html_document:</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC4'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;css: custom.css</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC5'>---</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC6'># Weight lifting excercises</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC7'>&lt;/BR&gt;</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC8'>&lt;/BR&gt;</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC9'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC10'>## Introduction ##</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC11'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC12'>The aim of this piece of work is to explore using machine learning to determine how &quot;correctly&quot; one perfroms their physical workout. This is extremely important especially in atheletes and elderlies who are more susceptible to injuries from physical workouts.</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC13'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC14'>In this study, large amount of data were collected from 6 participants. These data were from accelerometers on the belt, forearm, arm, and dumbell. The participant were asked to perform barbell lifts correctly and incorrectly in 5 different ways.</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC15'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC16'>In this work, the sensor data are being divided into 3 datasets. The training set, the testing set and the validation set. </div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC17'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC18'>The strategy adopted to perform the machine learning is as follows:</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC19'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC20'>1. Perform out of sample error estimation by applying the prediction model on the testing dataset</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC23'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC24'>3. Select the most accurate prediction model</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC25'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC26'>4. Apply the selected model on the validation set</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC27'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC28'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC29'>```{r getfiles,cache=TRUE, message=FALSE,warning=FALSE,error=FALSE}</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC30'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC31'># download and read the training and Keep data with complete cases</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC61'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC62'>```{r preprocess strategy, cache=TRUE, message=FALSE,warning=FALSE,error=FALSE}</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC63'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC64'>#remove near zero value</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC65'>nzv &lt;- nearZeroVar(train)</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC66'>train.process &lt;- train[,-nzv]</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC67'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC68'>#remove columns with large number of NA</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC69'>na.test &lt;- function(x) {</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC70'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;sum(is.na(x))</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC71'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;}</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC72'>try &lt;- apply(train.process,2,na.test)</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC73'>try &lt;- try/nrow(train.process)*100    #percentage of NAs in each column</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC74'>try.select &lt;- data.frame(try[try&lt;0.9])  #keep columns having less than 90% of NA values, ie more         than 90% of enerties are NA, we discard the column</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC75'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC76'>train.process &lt;- subset(train.process, select=c(rownames(try.select)))</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC77'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC78'>#remove some column names such as &quot;X&quot;, &quot;user_name&quot;, &quot;raw_timestamp_part_1&quot;, </div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC79'>#&quot;raw_timestamp_part_2&quot;, &quot;cvtd_timestamp&quot;, &quot;num_window&quot; </div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC80'>train.process &lt;- train.process[,-(1:6)]</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC81'>train.proC &lt;- train.process[complete.cases(train.process),]   #keep only completecase enteries</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC82'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC83'>```</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC84'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC85'>## Machine Learning</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC86'>To ensure the reproducibility of the results, 4567 is set as the seed for the calculations.</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC87'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC88'>The models experimented include</div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC89'><br></div><div class='line js-file-line' id='LC90'>1.
